name: Nmap
text:
Pre-requirements

Networking - course to understand everything that is written in this course.

Linux basics - course to understand everything that is written in this course.

Operating - Systems course to understand everything that is written in this course.

Recommendations

Lua - course to understand how to write Nmap scripts.

WARNING

IF you want to understand EVERYTHING that is written in this course you HAVE TO complete courses that are shown in Pre-requirements window.

Intro

Nmap is widely used tool for gathering information about networks and hosts.Attackers can get very helpful information about target with Nmap.After mastering Nmap you will be able to scan networks and discover live hosts, scan hosts and gather information about what is running on the host(Operating system, Service and etc).

Installation of Nmap

If you are a Windows user you can download Nmap from: https://nmap.org/download.html

If you are a Linux user, here are some examples how you can download Nmap:

  1. Debian based distros -
    2. > sudo apt install nmap

    If you have a problem with installing Nmap, try updating your system by:

    > sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade
  2. Debian based distros -
    3. > sudo apt install nmap

    If you have a problem with installing Nmap, try updating your system by:

    > sudo pacman -Syu
  3. Void linux -
    4. > sudo xbps-install -S nmap

    If you have a problem with installing Nmap, try updating your system by:

    > sudo xbps-install -Su

Basics of Nmap

Nmap is widely used tool for gathering information about networks and hosts.Attackers can get very helpful information about target with Nmap.After mastering Nmap you will be able to scan networks and discover live hosts, scan hosts and gather information about what is running on the host(Operating system, Service and etc).

> nmap <IPv4Here>

Do not write it is just for you to see where you need to write target's IP.Output will show you that there is HTTP port opened on TCP port 80.Now you know that target has HTTP port and it acts like web server.You can try to get more information about target with command flags.As you know almost every command has flags.Nmap with default scan only scans from 1 to 1000 ports but you know that maximum port number is 65535.If you want to scan all ports you can use '-p-' flag.Actually this flag is '-p' and it helps you to specify which ports you need to scan.For example:

> nmap <IPv4Here> -p 80

Will only scan port 80.If you want to scan all of the ports you can put '-' at the end of the flag and command will look like this:

> nmap <IPv4Here> -p-

With this flag nmap will scan all ports(From 1 to 65535).You discoverd that target also had port 9011 opened.

Now let's image that you did not have 'targets.txt' file to see your target's IPv4 address.With help of Nmap you can discover live hosts in your LAN.For that you have to use Ping scan flag '-sn' and you must know netmask of your network.Command will be:

> nmap -sn <IPv4HereWithNetmask>

Output will show every host that has been discovered.Remember that this is ping scan and if any host will not answer ICMP request Nmap will not discover it so you can't discover hosts in other VLAN that is seperated from your VLAN and does not accept any request from your VLAN(Maybe switch is configured like that).

In some cases you need to stay quiet in network but somethimes you have to be aggressive.'-T' flag will help you with that.It is timing template flag that has 6 levels(From 0 to 5).If you want to stay quiet you can use low numbers like 0, 1 and 2 but if you want to be aggressive try numbers 3, 4 and 5.Remember that it takes more time to scan anything if you are passive and it takes less time if you are more aggressive.Here are examples:

  1. Scan to stay quiet -
    2. > nmap -T 1 <IPv4Here>
  2. Scan aggressively -
    3. > nmap -T 5 <IPv4Here>

Intermediate Nmap

If you want to detect OS(Operating System) on your target you can use '-O' flag.It enables OS detection but remember somethimes Nmap is not able to get information about target's OS.This will be command:

> nmap -O <IPv4Here>

Nmap also has more additional flags for OS detection.Here are all explained:

  1. '--osscan-limit' - OS detection is more effective when one TCP port is opened and one is closed.If you will give Nmap this flag it will not try to detect OS on machines that does not fit in that criteria.
  2. '--osscan-guess' - When Nmap is not able to detect OS it can offer you some guesses.
  3. '--osscan-guess' - When Nmap is not able to detect OS it can offer you some guesses.

As you know when connecting to any host on any port you also use your own port to use that(Source port).If you want to specify sourse port Nmap has flag for you.You can use '-g' or '--source-port' to specify sourse port.For example:

> nmap -g 473 <IPv4Here>

OR

> nmap --sourse-port 473 <IPv4Here>

In both situations Nmap will use port 473 as source port.

Now let's talk about service version detection.You already discovered that your target has opened HTTP port.But to hack any service you need other information.For example what web server and which version of that web server is being used on the server.To detect all of that you can use '-sV' flag.It is version detection flag.You can use it in command like that:

> nmap -sV <IPv4Here>

Nmap also has more additional flags for service detection. Here are all explained:

  1. '--version-intensity' - This flag allows you to choose levels of version detections.It can be from 0 to 9.For example:
  2. '--version-light' - This flag is like '--version-intensity' but it enables only lightmode scan.It will be fast but gathered information will not be much.
  3. '--version-all' - This is an alias for '--version-intensity 9'.
  4. '--version-trace' - This will output every detail when version detection is going.
  5. '--allports' - This flag will tell Nmap to do not exlude any port from service detection.

Output will show you service versions.As you see your target uses Apache web server.If Nmap wrote apache version in the output you already have huge information about target.All version has its own vulnerability and its exploit.You at least can search it online and get code for exploit.If you are skilled programmer you can search sourse code of that spesific version of in this case apache and read it.In code you will find bugs and mistakes.Depending on that bugs you can develop your own exploit.If you are even more skilled person and know reverse engineering(Check out Reverse Engineering course) you can reverse already compiled code and find bugs.

If your computer has more than one interfaces you can tell Nmap to use spesific one.For example you have 'eth0' and 'eth1'.You can specify which one to use with '-e' flag.In command you can write it like this:

> nmap -e eth1 <IPv4Here>

Some packet filters have trouble dealing with IP packet fragments.There is also the possibility that fragments will take different paths and that prevents packet reassembly.To prevent those things to happen you can use '-f' flag.This means packet fragmentation.Nmap will use tiny fragments if you enable '-f' flag.This flag can add 8 bits in the fragment.Command will look like this:

> nmap -f <IPv4Here>

Remember, fragmentation is only supported on raw packets.

If you want to bypass IP layer you can use '--send-eth' flag.When this flag is enabled Nmap will send raw ethernet packets.Here is command:

> nmap --send-eth <IPv4Here>

If you want to bypass IP layer you can use '--send-eth' flag.When this flag is enabled Nmap will send raw ethernet packets.Here is command:

> nmap --send-eth <IPv4Here>

You can incrase verbose and debuggin level on Nmap.Verbose level is increased by adding '-v' flag in the command.Debugging level is increased by adding '-d' flag in the command.Here are commands you can try:

  1. Increase verbose by 1 -
    2. > nmap -v <IPv4Here>
  2. Increase verbose by 2 -
    3. > nmap -vv <IPv4Here>
  3. Increase debugging by 1 -
    4. >nmap -d <IPv4Here>
  4. Increase debugging by 2 -
    5. > nmap -dd <IPv4Here>

Outro

You have learned lot's of things you can do with Nmap.You can practice it in the terminal(right side).If you want to learn Nmap scripts check out Nmap scripts course.In that course you will learn Advanced usages of Nmap.Also you will have access on bigger LAB to practice usage of all scripts.
